title: Biden Announces Three Nominees for Postal Service Board of Governors
sub_head: President said his nominees would ensure the agency ‘can effectively and efficiently serve all communities in our country’
body:
WASHINGTON—President Biden announced three nominees to the U.S. Postal Service’s Board of Governors, saying they would make sure the agency “can effectively and efficiently serve all communities in our country.”
The president said Wednesday he was nominating Anton Hajjar, a former general counsel of the American Postal Workers Union; Amber McReynolds, chief executive of the National Vote at Home Institute, a nonprofit that advocates for improved mail-in voting; and Ron Stroman, a former deputy postmaster general who led Mr. Biden’s transition team for postal-service issues.
If confirmed, they will fill three vacant seats on the nine-member board, which currently has six appointees of former President Donald Trump, two of whom are Democrats. The postmaster general serves at the pleasure of the board.
The announcement came as the House Oversight and Reform Committee heard testimony on Wednesday from Postmaster General Louis DeJoy, a North Carolina businessman and Republican donor who was tapped by the board for the position last year.
Democrats have urged Mr. Biden to fill the vacant board seats in hopes that the new picks would help oust Mr. DeJoy amid criticism over mail-delivery delays.
